title: Using smartrank
code: fruits <- c("Apple", "Orange", "Apple", "Pear", "Orange")  # rank alphabetically smartrank(fruits) #> [1] 1.5 3.5 1.5 5.0 3.5  # rank based on frequency smartrank(fruits, sort_by = "frequency") #> [1] 2.5 4.5 2.5 1.0 4.5  # rank based on descending order of frequency smartrank(fruits, sort_by = "frequency", desc = TRUE) #> [1] 3.5 1.5 3.5 5.0 1.5

title: Using smartrank

code: fruits <- c("Apple", "Orange", "Apple", "Pear", "Orange") ranks <- smartrank(fruits, sort_by = "frequency") fruits[order(ranks)] #> [1] "Pear"   "Apple"  "Apple"  "Orange" "Orange"

title: Using smartrank

title: Using smartrank
text: example, can sort following dataframe based frequency fruits, break ties based alphabetical order picker.
code: data = data.frame(     fruits = c("Apple", "Orange", "Apple", "Pear", "Orange"),     picker = c("Elizabeth", "Damian",  "Bob", "Cameron", "Alice") )  # Rank fruits so the most frequently picked fruits will come first fruit_ranks <- smartrank(data$fruits, sort_by = "frequency", desc=TRUE)    # Rank pickers in alphabetical order picker_ranks <- smartrank(data$picker, sort_by = "alphabetical", desc=FALSE)   # Sort dataframe by the fruit_ranks, then the picker_ranks (hierarchical) data[order(fruit_ranks, picker_ranks),] #>   fruits    picker #> 5 Orange     Alice #> 2 Orange    Damian #> 3  Apple       Bob #> 1  Apple Elizabeth #> 4   Pear   Cameron

title: Using smartrank
text: equivalent way hierarchically sort data.frames use smartrank() tidyverse arrange() function.
code: library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  arrange(   data,    smartrank(fruits, "frequency", desc = TRUE),    smartrank(picker, "alphabetical", desc = FALSE) ) #>   fruits    picker #> 1 Orange     Alice #> 2 Orange    Damian #> 3  Apple       Bob #> 4  Apple Elizabeth #> 5   Pear   Cameron

what: Customisable Ranking of Numerical and Categorical Data
title: Customisable Ranking of Numerical and Categorical Data
text: Rank provides customizable alternative built-rank() function. package offers following features: Frequency-based ranking categorical variables: choose whether rank based alphabetic order element frequency. Control sorting order: Use desc=TRUE rank based descending ascending order.

code: install.packages("rank") # install.packages('remotes') remotes::install_github("selkamand/rank")

title: Customisable Ranking of Numerical and Categorical Data
code: library(rank)  fruits <- c("Apple", "Orange", "Apple", "Pear", "Orange")  # rank alphabetically smartrank(fruits) #> [1] 1.5 3.5 1.5 5.0 3.5  # rank based on frequency smartrank(fruits, sort_by = "frequency") #> [1] 2.5 4.5 2.5 1.0 4.5  # rank based on descending order of frequency smartrank(fruits, sort_by = "frequency", desc = TRUE) #> [1] 3.5 1.5 3.5 5.0 1.5

what: Ranking and reordering by priority values
title: Customisable Ranking of Numerical and Categorical Data
text: rank_by_priority() assigns highest ranks specified values (order), remaining values share lower rank.reorder_by_priority() uses ranks move priority values front vector.
code: # Prioritise D first, then C; A and B follow in original order rank_by_priority(c("A", "B", "C", "D"), priority_values = c("D", "C")) #> [1] 3.5 3.5 2.0 1.0  # Reorder so priorities come first reorder_by_priority(c("A", "B", "C", "D"), priority_values = c("D", "C")) #> [1] "D" "C" "A" "B"

title: Customisable Ranking of Numerical and Categorical Data
text: rank_stratified() computes single combined rank across columns data frame, column ranked within groups defined previous columns. produces true hierarchical ordering. smartrank can used arrange data.frames based one columns, maintaining complete control column contributes final row order.
code: data <- data.frame(   gender = c("male", "male", "male", "male", "female", "female", "male", "female"),   pet    = c("cat", "cat", "magpie", "magpie", "giraffe", "cat", "giraffe", "cat") )  # Hierarchical ranking: # 1. Rank gender (globally, by frequency) # 2. Within each gender, rank pet by within-gender frequency r <- rank_stratified(   data,   sort_by = c("frequency", "frequency"),   desc    = TRUE )  data[order(r), ] #>   gender     pet #> 3   male  magpie #> 4   male  magpie #> 1   male     cat #> 2   male     cat #> 7   male giraffe #> 6 female     cat #> 8 female     cat #> 5 female giraffe

title: Customisable Ranking of Numerical and Categorical Data
text: example, can sort following dataframe based frequency fruits, break ties based alphabetical order picker.
code: data <- data.frame(   fruits = c("Apple", "Orange", "Apple", "Pear", "Orange"),   picker = c("Elizabeth", "Damian", "Bob", "Cameron", "Alice") )  # Rank_stratified(): # 1. Rank fruits by frequency (globally) # 2. Within each fruit, rank pickers alphabetically strat_ranks <- rank_stratified(   data,   cols = c("fruits", "picker"),   sort_by = c("frequency", "alphabetical"),   desc = c(TRUE, FALSE) )  data[order(strat_ranks), ] #>   fruits    picker #> 5 Orange     Alice #> 2 Orange    Damian #> 3  Apple       Bob #> 1  Apple Elizabeth #> 4   Pear   Cameron

title: Customisable Ranking of Numerical and Categorical Data
text: equivalent way hierarchically sort data.frames use tidyverse arrange() function
code: library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  arrange(   data,   rank_stratified(     data,     cols = c("fruits", "picker"),     sort_by = c("frequency", "alphabetical"),     desc = c(TRUE, FALSE)   ) ) #>   fruits    picker #> 1 Orange     Alice #> 2 Orange    Damian #> 3  Apple       Bob #> 4  Apple Elizabeth #> 5   Pear   Cameron

what: Stratified hierarchical ranking across multiple variables — rank_stratified
title: Stratified hierarchical ranking across multiple variables — rank_stratified
text: rank_stratified() computes single, combined rank row data frame using stratified hierarchical ranking. first variable ranked globally; subsequent variable ranked within strata defined previous variables.

title: Stratified hierarchical ranking across multiple variables — rank_stratified
code: rank_stratified(   data,   cols = NULL,   sort_by = "frequency",   desc = FALSE,   ties.method = "average",   na.last = TRUE,   freq_tiebreak = "match_desc",   verbose = TRUE )

title: Stratified hierarchical ranking across multiple variables — rank_stratified
text: data data frame. selected column represents one level stratified hierarchy, order given cols. cols Optional column specification indicating variables data use ranking, order. Can : NULL (default): use columns data existing order. character vector column names. integer vector column positions. sort_by Character scalar vector specifying rank non-numeric column. element must either "alphabetical" "frequency", matching behaviour smartrank(). single value supplied recycled columns. numeric columns, sort_by ignored ranking always based numeric order. desc Logical scalar vector indicating whether rank column descending order. single value supplied recycled columns. ties.method Passed base::rank() resolving ties level; must one "average", "first", "last", "random", "max", "min". See base::rank() details. na.last Logical, controlling treatment missing values, base::rank(). TRUE, NAs given largest ranks; FALSE, smallest. Unlike base::rank() smartrank(), na.last set NA rank_stratified(), dropping rows change group membership break stratified ranking. freq_tiebreak Character scalar vector controlling alphabetical tie-breaking works sort_by = "frequency" column character/factor/logical. element must one : "match_desc" (default): alphabetical tie-breaking follows desc column (ascending desc = FALSE, descending desc = TRUE). "asc": ties always broken ascending alphabetical order. "desc": ties always broken descending alphabetical order. single value supplied, recycled columns. verbose Logical; TRUE, emit messages sort_by ignored (e.g. numeric columns), mirroring behaviour smartrank().

title: Stratified hierarchical ranking across multiple variables — rank_stratified
text: numeric vector length nrow(data), containing stratified ranks. Smaller values indicate "earlier" rows stratified hierarchy.

title: Stratified hierarchical ranking across multiple variables — rank_stratified
text: useful want "truly hierarchical" ordering , example, rows first grouped ordered frequency gender, within gender group, ordered frequency pet within gender, rather globally. result single rank vector can passed directly base::order() obtain stratified, multi-level ordering. Stratified ranking proceeds level level: first selected column ranked globally, using sort_by[1] (non-numeric) desc[1]. second column, ranks computed separately within distinct combination values previous columns. Within stratum, second column ranked using sort_by[2] / desc[2]. process continues subsequent column: level k, ranking done within strata defined columns 1, 2, ..., k-1. yields single composite rank per row reflects "true" hierarchical (.e. stratified) ordering: earlier variables define strata, later variables compared within strata (example, within-stratum frequency).

title: Stratified hierarchical ranking across multiple variables — rank_stratified
code: library(rank)  data <- data.frame(   gender = c("male", "male", "male", "male", "female", "female", "male", "female"),   pet    = c("cat",  "cat",  "magpie", "magpie", "giraffe", "cat", "giraffe", "cat") )  # Stratified ranking: first by gender frequency, then within each gender # by pet frequency *within that gender* r <- rank_stratified(   data,   cols = c("gender", "pet"),   sort_by = c("frequency", "frequency"),   desc = TRUE )  data[order(r), ] #>   gender     pet #> 3   male  magpie #> 4   male  magpie #> 1   male     cat #> 2   male     cat #> 7   male giraffe #> 6 female     cat #> 8 female     cat #> 5 female giraffe

title: Rank a vector based on either alphabetical or frequency order — smartrank
text: x numeric, character, factor vector sort_by Sort ranking either "alphabetical" "frequency" . Default "alphabetical" desc logical indicating whether ranking descending ( TRUE ) ascending ( FALSE ) order. input numeric, ranking always based numeric order. ties.method character string specifying ties treated,     see ‘Details’; can abbreviated. na.last logical character string controlling treatment     NAs. TRUE, missing values data     put last; FALSE, put first; NA,     removed; "keep" kept rank NA. freq_tiebreak Controls alphabetical tie-breaking works sort_by = "frequency" x character/factor/logical. Must one : "match_desc" (default): alphabetical tie-breaking direction follows desc (ascending desc = FALSE, descending desc = TRUE). "asc": ties always broken ascending alphabetical order, regardless desc. "desc": ties always broken descending alphabetical order, regardless desc. verbose verbose (flag)

title: Rank a vector based on either alphabetical or frequency order — smartrank
text: ranked vector

title: Rank a vector based on either alphabetical or frequency order — smartrank
text: x includes ‘ties’ (equal values), ties.method argument determines rank value decided. Must one : average: replaces integer ranks tied values average  (default) first: first-occurring value assumed lower rank (closer one) last: last-occurring value assumed lower rank (closer one) max min: integer ranks tied values replaced maximum minimum respectively (latter typical sports-ranking) random tied values higher / lower rank randomly decided. NA values never considered equal: na.last = TRUE na.last = FALSE given distinct ranks order occur x.

title: Rank a vector based on either alphabetical or frequency order — smartrank
text: sort_by = "frequency", ties based frequency broken alphabetical order terms. Use freq_tiebreak control whether alphabetical tie-breaking ascending, descending, follows desc. sort_by = "frequency" input character, ties.method ignored. distinct element level gets rank, rank 1 unit away next element, irrespective many duplicates

title: Rank a vector based on either alphabetical or frequency order — smartrank
code: # ------------------ ## CATEGORICAL INPUT # ------------------  fruits <- c("Apple", "Orange", "Apple", "Pear", "Orange")  # rank alphabetically smartrank(fruits) #> [1] 1.5 3.5 1.5 5.0 3.5 #> [1] 1.5 3.5 1.5 5.0 3.5  # rank based on frequency smartrank(fruits, sort_by = "frequency") #> [1] 2.5 4.5 2.5 1.0 4.5 #> [1] 2.5 4.5 2.5 1.0 4.5  # rank based on descending order of frequency smartrank(fruits, sort_by = "frequency", desc = TRUE) #> [1] 3.5 1.5 3.5 5.0 1.5 #> [1] 1.5 3.5 1.5 5.0 3.5  # sort fruits vector based on rank ranks <- smartrank(fruits,sort_by = "frequency", desc = TRUE) fruits[order(ranks)] #> [1] "Orange" "Orange" "Apple"  "Apple"  "Pear"   #> [1] "Apple"  "Apple"  "Orange" "Orange" "Pear"   # ------------------ ## NUMERICAL INPUT # ------------------  # rank numerically smartrank(c(1, 3, 2)) #> [1] 1 3 2 #> [1] 1 3 2  # rank numerically based on descending order smartrank(c(1, 3, 2), desc = TRUE) #> [1] 3 1 2 #> [1] 3 1 2  # always rank numeric vectors based on values, irrespective of sort_by smartrank(c(1, 3, 2), sort_by = "frequency") #> smartrank: Sorting a non-categorical variable. Ignoring `sort_by` and sorting numerically #> [1] 1 3 2 #> smartrank: Sorting a non-categorical variable. Ignoring `sort_by` and sorting numerically #> [1] 1 3 2
